module.p: taidhcùn tycoon is a (masculine) occupational common noun.

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through duty, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5
Bha a h-uile duine a dh’aithnicheadh e a’ smaoineachadh gu robh beatha shòlasach aig Ailig Smart. [...] Thòisich e na bhalach le aon eathar ghiomach ag obair a-mach à Malaig, agus aig an àm seo bha e air a mheas na dhuine beairteach. Bha trì bàtaichean mòr aige, agus bha e a’ reic iomadh seòrsa maoraich anns an Fhraing agus anns an Spàinn. A dh’aindeoin sin, cha robh e air a shèideadh suas le fèin-spèis idir, mar as tric a bhios taidhcùn. ’S ann glè ainneamh a chitheadh duine e air a sgeadachadh mar duine-uasal. Mar bu tric’ ’s e geansaidh iasgair agus seann bhriogais a bhiodh air, oir bha e daonnan ag obair mu eathraichean is iasg. [...]
Everybody who got to know him thought that Alec Smart had a good life. [...] He started with one lobster boat working out of Mallaig, and at this time he had been regarded as a wealthy man. He had three large boats, and he sold many types of shellfish in France and in Spain. Besides that, he was not inflated with self-regard at all, as a tycoon often is. He was very seldom seen dressed like a gentleman. Usually, he wore a fisherman’s jersey, because he was always working around boats and fish. [...] td. 103
Gaelic taidhcùn is borrowed/transliterated from English tycoon wealthy and powerful business person, itself borrowed/transliterated from Japanese 大君 (taikun) great lord, prince.
